Q93_11_TEXT: Faculty, staff and graduate students in their office spaces
Q17: 9 participants were administrative staff, 3 research staff, 1 faculty, and 1 graduate student. We did not collect income or education level but all participants had at least a Bachelors degree. Income level for participants should be medium except for graduate student based on their job role but we did not explicitely collect this information.
Q21_7_TEXT: This study used personal comfort system, so each occupant had the system in their desks. Occupancy was monitored using a motion sensor at each desk.
Q105_6_TEXT: 2 intermediate levels of control between fully manual and fully automated
Q107: Online system (complaints tracked and stored in a database),Other
Q107_7_TEXT: The user interface was a touchscreen run on a raspberry pi. UI was similar to a phone app but was part of the developed system.
Q152: Intervention related to system and control
Q91: Aware that intervention is occurring,Aware how intervention is implemented
Q62_1_TEXT: If occupant was not present, the devices were not controlled. If occupants were present, then ML models were used to predict thermal sensation and actuate appropriate devices.
Q251: Thermal environmental sensor data (i.e.: temperature, humidity sensors)
Q250: Baseline did not involve PCS(fans or heaters). There were 4 levels of automation that were evaluated: manual, inquisitive, adaptive, and full automation. The average thermal satisfaction in baseline was -0.643 and highest thermal satisfaction was for inquisitive automation at 1.214 on the 7 point scale. Results for all conditions are in the shared paper.

Q17: This study investigates the influence of different environmental parameters in the self-perceived productivity of office workers, considering a living laboratory. Surveys about self-perceived productivity, comfort perception and sensation were asked in fall and summer in 5 offices in a living laboratory environment. Statistical tests were performed to check the correlation between the various env. domains and the productivity. Study still under evaluation for conference publication.
